title: Harry Truman: The Everyman President
description: Jeffrey Frank’s “The Trials of Harry S. Truman” recounts the great decisions of a president who was forced to overcome his limitations.
content: THE TRIALS OF HARRY S. TRUMANThe Extraordinary Presidency of an Ordinary Man, 1945-1953
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Reclaiming time lost to Covid
description: And a note to our readers.
content: Two years ago today, the World Health Organization declared the Covid-19 outbreak a global pandemic. A week before that, this newsletter was born. Since then, we’ve been on a journey together — braving waves of infections, experiencing sickness and loss, mastering the art of protecting ourselves, and continuously learning about a wily virus that seemed to surprise experts at every turn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: What Do I Do With All My Old Ties?
description: A reader asks for advice on relinquishing, or repurposing, unworn neckwear.
content: I imagine there is an ocean of men with the same problem: a tie rack full of ties and nowhere to wear them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose
title: Bitcoin Was Made for This Moment. So Why Isn’t It Booming?
description: Long hailed by its advocates as a safe hedge during uncertain times, Bitcoin’s value has fallen steadily in recent weeks.
content: For years, Bitcoin buffs who were questioned by skeptics about the value of the cryptocurrency would respond by saying: just wait.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: How a Line of Russian Tanks Became an Inviting Target for Ukrainians
description: A skirmish in an eastern suburb of Kyiv illustrated how close Russian forces have come as they continued to tighten a noose on the city, but also revealed their strategic vulnerabilities.
content: BROVARY, Ukraine — The column of Russian tanks rumbled along a main highway to the east of Kyiv, between two rows of houses in a small town — a vulnerable target.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kristen Bayrakdarian
title: Opening Up to Marriage, and Motherhood
description: When Deborah Shih-Chi Hsieh met Wei Lien Stephen Dang, he was a widower with two young daughters. She found a way to “step in and do this thing” with faith.
content: Before Deborah Shih-Chi Hsieh left her apartment in Washington at the beginning of the pandemic and moved back into her parents’ home in Tempe, Ariz., she had a job that offered little flexibility when it came to dating.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: Texas Court Halts Abuse Inquiries Into Parents of Transgender Children
description: A judge said the governor’s order to consider medically accepted treatments for transgender youth as abuse had been improperly adopted and violated the State Constitution.
content: HOUSTON — Investigations of parents with transgender children for possible child abuse were temporarily halted across Texas on Friday after a state court ruled that the policy, ordered last month by Gov. Greg Abbott, had been improperly adopted and violated the State Constitution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat
title: Flu Vaccine Was Not Very Effective This Season, the C.D.C. Says
description: The vaccine was only about 16 percent effective at reducing a person’s chance of getting a mild or moderate infection, the agency said. Experts said a good rate would be at least 50 percent.
content: This season’s flu vaccine has offered little to no protection against getting a mild or moderate case of influenza, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Alderman and Jenny Gross
title: Russian Sanctions Snarl Shipping Even as Pandemic Pressure Eases
description: Global disruptions from the war on Ukraine and uncertainty due to the sanctions have led to pileups at ports and could delay cargo longer.
content: Russian ships banned from docking in Britain. Cargo containers piling up at European ports. Airfreight rerouted around Ukraine and Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: With Trump in Her State, Haley Finds Some Political Distance (Gently)
description: Nikki Haley, the former United Nations ambassador, used a well-timed endorsement of Representative Nancy Mace to get on the opposite side of the former president.
content: WASHINGTON — Rumors were swirling in South Carolina early this February that Donald J. Trump would try to tear down a Republican congresswoman who had incurred his wrath.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Gessen
title: President Zelensky Makes His Case for Ukraine to the Russian People
description: Americans are used to wars against people who don’t so casually speak our language. Zelensky can respond to Russian propaganda by directly addressing the Russian people — in Russian.
content: The thing about the videos from the war in Ukraine in 2014 was that there were very few war videos. It was, at least at first, a small-arms war. Fighting, when it erupted, happened on city streets. As soon as shots were fired, whoever was making the video would put away the phone and run.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Late-Winter Storm Set to Sweep Across the U.S. Into Saturday
description: Winter weather alerts were in effect on Friday from Tennessee to Maine. The Northeast will receive the most snow, with some places expecting a foot or more, meteorologists said.
content: A sprawling, late-season winter storm was forecast to bring a mixed bag of precipitation across a wide stretch of the United States through Saturday, raising concerns about hazardous driving conditions and scattered power failures, meteorologists said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kara Swisher
title: Florida Lawmakers Advance Homophobia to DeSantis’s Desk
description: The so-called Don’t Say Gay bill teaches all the wrong things; expect it to be approved.
content: In a move that gave me a feeling of toxic déjà vu from the anti-gay-marriage Proposition 8 in California in 2008, Florida’s so-called Don’t Say Gay bill has passed both houses of the state legislature and is headed to the desk of Gov. Ron DeSantis, where he is expected to sign it. The legislation is aimed at limiting what can be taught in classrooms about sexual orientation and gender identity, and also gives parents the right to sue schools or teachers if they believe what is being taught is unacceptable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ryan Mac and Kellen Browning
title: Apps and Oranges: Behind Apple’s ‘Bullying’ on Trademarks
description: The company has opposed singer-songwriters, school districts and food blogs for trying to trademark names or logos featuring an apple — or a pear or pineapple.
content: When Genevieve St. John started a sex-and-life coaching blog in 2019, she designed a logo for the business of a neon green and pink apple, which was cut open to resemble female genitalia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Daniels
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘How the Lab-Grown Chicken Is Made’
description: In this lesson, students will learn about how cellular meat could be the future of food production. Would you be willing to eat it?
content: This lesson is a part of our Accessible Activities feature, which aims to welcome a wider variety of learners to our site and to The Times. Learn more and tell us what you think here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Court Declares Man Wrongfully Imprisoned for 45 Years
description: The official declaration this week means that Isaiah Andrews, 84, can seek damages from the State of Ohio for spending more than half his life in prison after being wrongly convicted of killing his wife.
content: For decades, Isaiah Andrews has maintained his innocence in the 1974 murder of his wife, unaware that the key to his exoneration was buried in the archives of the Cleveland Division of Police.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: The Supreme Court Did the Right Thing. I’m Still Worried.
description: A breathtaking claim about the nature of state legislative power was rejected. But for how long?
content: State legislatures are, and always have been, creatures of state constitutions, bound by the terms of those constitutions and subject to the judgments of state courts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: Lockdowns spread in China as the virus surges in Shanghai and over a dozen provinces.
description: Officials say that most of the recent cases detected in widespread testing are asymptomatic but still contagious.
content: BEIJING — Cinemas, theaters and museums have closed in downtown Shanghai, and tickets have been refunded. The vast city’s school system announced late Friday that it would switch to online learning. And across China, more than 100 neighborhoods have been labeled medium-risk or high-risk Covid zones, with frequent mandatory testing and partial or complete lockdowns.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Brief History of Bras in Crosswords
description: In Monday’s puzzle, BRA was the answer to the clue “Undergarment with cups.”
content: This is Clued In, a column that will give you insight into some of the New York Times Crossword clues and answers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta
title: A growing force in the climate movement: Moms
description: Activists are deploying the moral authority of mothers to push for climate action. Their protests must steer clear of nap time.
content: Many of you write to us and tell us about your feelings of powerlessness in the face of a global climate catastrophe. That sentiment is giving rise to a small but potentially potent force in the climate movement: moms, who have been catapulted into action by the hazards facing their children.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: An Israeli Skier Shines, but Does Not Compromise, at the Paralympics
description: Sheina Vaspi’s membership in the Chabad movement of Judaism led to her wearing a skirt on the slopes. But skiing on the Sabbath was a nonstarter.
content: YANQING, China — Just as it was becoming clear that Sheina Vaspi had the talent and drive to compete internationally, she faced a difficult choice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deborah B. Solomon and Amir Hamja
title: Millions in Stimulus Aid, and Clashing Over How to Spend It
description: As communities across the United States receive pandemic relief money, fierce debates have erupted over priorities, and who has the power to set them.
content: Last June, a meeting of the Dutchess County Legislature in New York’s Hudson Valley quickly turned heated over how to spend some of the county’s $57 million in federal pandemic relief aid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Allen
title: ‘Wozzeck,’ the 20th Century’s Most Influential Opera, Turns 100
description: Alban Berg’s brutal classic, a tale of a lowly soldier’s degradation and death, continues to inspire artists.
content: Theodor Adorno had to commiserate with Alban Berg late into the night on Dec. 14, 1925, after the premiere of “Wozzeck” at the Berlin State Opera.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Fall Back? Spring Ahead? How About Neither, Experts Say.
description: Here’s where the debate over changing the clocks stands, and what it could mean for you.
content: On Sunday, most people in the United States will “spring” their clocks forward by one hour, heralding the end of standard time (with its brighter mornings and darker evenings) and the beginning of daylight saving time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: America’s Right Has a Putin Problem
description: They knew he was brutal, but didn’t expect incompetence.
content: Just a few weeks ago many influential figures on the U.S. right loved, just loved Vladimir Putin. In fact, some of them still can’t quit him. For example, Tucker Carlson, while he has grudgingly backed off from full-on Putin support, is still blaming America for the war and promoting Russian disinformation about U.S.-funded bioweapons labs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Chang Chien
title: Disabled Chinese Fight for Equal Rights Despite Paralympic Glory
description: Outside the Games, people with disabilities in China face discrimination and a lack of opportunities. “I’ve been struggling to survive,” said one former Paralympian.
content: BEIJING — As Li Xiang strapped himself into a seat mounted atop a single ski and raced down the snowy slope, he reveled in the feeling of freedom that had become all too rare after a car accident required him to use a wheelchair as a child.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Congress Clears $1.5 Trillion Spending Bill, Including Ukraine Aid
description: President Biden is expected to sign the measure, the first major spending bill since he took office.
content: WASHINGTON — Congress cleared the first major federal spending legislation of President Biden’s administration on Thursday, approving a $1.5 trillion measure with substantial increases for domestic and national security programs, along with $13.6 billion in emergency aid for Ukraine as it battles Russia’s invasion.
source.name: The New York Times

source.name: The New York Times

title: Why Senate Republicans Are Feuding Over Their Midterm Message
description: Senator Rick Scott has an 11-point plan to “rescue America.” Senator Mitch McConnell would rather he not.
content: Republican insiders have long worried that they could blow a golden opportunity to retake the Senate this year. And while most are confident that a red wave will still wash enough of their candidates ashore in November to win a majority, some doubt occasionally creeps in.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Help! How Do I Get My Sex Drive Back?
description: Advice on how to restore a decline in sexual desire.
content: Q: Are there any proven treatments for low libido in women?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judy Mandell
title: Playing Sidekick, Each Found Their Soul Mate
description: Stephanie Osimiri and Jason Capps were tagging along on another date when they met — and sparked a connection that endured.
content: When Jason William Capps agreed to accompany his best friend on a casual date in late 2010, it was after being promised that the woman his friend was meeting would bring a companion of her own. That companion was Stephanie Onyinye Osimiri.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nancy Ruhling
title: How a Gallery Owner Spends Her Sundays
description: Katja Hirche mixes museum outings with visits to a French bistro and the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.
content: As the owner of Bernd Goeckler, an art gallery in Greenwich Village, Katja Hirche curates a cutting-edge collection of contemporary artworks and antique furnishings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Bruce Duffy, Hailed for His Ambitious First Novel, Dies at 70
description: In “The World as I Found It,” he created a fictional biography of the philosopher Wittgenstein. But though acclaimed as an “emerging” star, he wrote only two more novels.
content: Bruce Duffy, an ambitious, inventive writer whose debut novel, “The World as I Found It” — with its improbable leading man, the Austrian philosopher Ludwig Wittgenstein — received rapturous reviews but nevertheless failed to make him a lasting literary star, died on Feb. 10 in hospice care in Rockville, Md. He was 70.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Kim
title: Chinese stocks listed in U.S. tumble over fears of potential delisting
description: The S.E.C. specified five U.S.-traded Chinese companies required to turn over audit information to regulators. The news reverberated in Asian markets Friday.
content: Chinese stocks listed in the United States saw their worst day of trading since 2008 on Thursday, driven by fears of potential delisting in U.S. markets under a law that requires the companies to hand over audit information to American regulators. Reverberations were felt in Chinese markets on Friday, where many shares had sharp declines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: The Case for Induction Cooking
description: As the perils of cooking with gas become more apparent, there’s ever more reason for cooks to turn to these flameless, easy-to-clean ranges.
content: Robert Osborne grew anxious about dinner when his Brooklyn co-op board put the kibosh on a plan to move a gas line for his kitchen renovation. How could Mr. Osborne, a math teacher, cook his favorite dishes like skillet chicken with caramelized mushrooms and onions if he couldn’t do it over the classic blue-orange blaze of a gas stove?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devika Girish
title: Five International Movies to Stream Now
description: This month’s picks include an otherworldly Mexican comedy, a tale of repressed romance from Georgia and an elliptical Brazilian thriller.
content: A narrative feature by the Mexican comedian Gabriel Nuncio, “This Is Not a Comedy” is a strange and audacious concoction of kooky, funny and sad. Gabriel, playing himself, is a down-and-out stand-up comedian in Mexico City with dreams of producing his first screenplay, about a female astronaut who goes to Mars. The story seems inspired by Gabriel’s girlfriend, the eccentric Leyre (Cassandra Ciangherotti), who talks to plants and believes that aliens will arrive soon to take her away. Her bright-eyed curiosity can’t seem to penetrate the cynical, broke-as-hell Gabriel, who is a repeat victim of Murphy’s law: In a running gag, he keeps forgetting his keys and has to have a locksmith break him into his apartment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan and Eileen Sullivan
title: Even Before War, Thousands Were Fleeing Russia for the U.S.
description: Political activists, L.G.B.T.Q. people and Jehovah’s Witnesses in Russia are crossing the southern border from Mexico in greater numbers. More Ukrainians are also heading to the United States.
content: LOS ANGELES — Last fall, Iuliia Shuvalova and Sergei Ignatev, a young Russian couple, sold their car and took out a loan to pay for a holiday at a beach resort on Mexico’s Riviera Maya.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Bracing for Losses, Democrats Look to Biden for a Reset
description: At a party retreat in Philadelphia, House Democrats hoped the president would offer a winning strategy heading into a challenging midterm election season.
content: PHILADELPHIA — House Democrats planned a retreat here this week hoping for a reset after a difficult period during which President Biden has been buffeted by rising gas prices, soaring inflation and sagging approval ratings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Evan Rail
title: ‘This Is Everyone’s Culture’: Ukraine’s Architectural Treasures Face Destruction
description: The country’s vast array of historic buildings, artworks and public squares are an integral part of Ukraine’s cultural identity. Amid the violence of war, many are being reduced to rubble.
content: Russia’s invasion of Ukraine brought searing images of human tragedy to witnesses around the world: thousands of civilians killed and injured; broken families, as mothers and children leave in search of refuge while fathers and other men stay behind to defend their country; and millions of refugees having already fled to neighboring countries, after just two weeks of war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Do You Keep a Journal?
description: Self-reflective writing can help you remember things and process your emotions. Have you ever wanted to try it?
content: Do you have a journal or diary? If so, what do you like to write about in it and why? Do you use it to keep track of joyful, difficult or memorable events in your life? Do you use it to process feelings? Give gratitude? Practice self-care? Do something else?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Heinrich
title: Woodblock Prints and Hindu Gods at Asia Week New York
description: The annual trade fair and cultural festival returns with dozens of exhibitions and a new digital focus.
content: For more than a decade, before the pandemic, collectors and private dealers of Asian antiquities would converge in New York every spring for annual auctions at half a dozen houses including Bonham’s, Christie’s and Sotheby’s. Many out-of-town dealers would set up shows of their own in hotels or partner galleries, while hometown galleries and museums mounted special exhibitions for the occasion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: Review: At Carnegie, Going Beyond the Rapid-Fire Vivaldi
description: Jupiter, a young ensemble from France, made its Carnegie Hall debut with a variety of moods and the gifted mezzo-soprano Lea Desandre.
content: Slow, serene, more floating than furious: A Vivaldi concert at Weill Recital Hall on Thursday began in decidedly un-Vivaldian style.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson and Keith Bradsher
title: China Has Tools to Help Russia’s Economy. None Are Big Enough to Save It.
description: Any financial lifeline that Beijing can offer Moscow involves taking on risk and won’t have the power to reverse the damage of sanctions imposed by the United States and its allies.
content: When the United States and its allies declared a financial war on Russia after its invasion of Ukraine, the world turned to see what China would do.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chisom Peter Job
title: When My Heart Broke, My Father Used Google to Save Me
description: And soon after, I told both of my parents who I really am.
content: After I came home from the hospital, my mother and father took turns sitting on my bed every night to make sure I was still breathing. My mother would rest her head on my chest and say a prayer. My father would whisper, “I love you,” and touch my cheek.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: If the Lockout Makes Baseball Better, It Will Have Been Worth It
description: After tense negotiations, Major League Baseball and the players’ union both made gains in their desired areas. But more important, they avoided losses — of games and, potentially, their standing.
content: At last, it is safe to say the only three words fans have cared about for months: Baseball is back. Major League Baseball and its players’ union reached an agreement Thursday on a collective bargaining agreement after 99 locked-out days of tedious rhetoric and posturing. Put ’em in, coach. They’re ready to play.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brandon Taylor

description: In Karen Joy Fowler’s new novel, “Booth,” readers get a window into the life of Abraham Lincoln’s killer.
content: BOOTHBy Karen Joy Fowler

title: The far right complains after the search engine DuckDuckGo vows to limit Russian propaganda.
description: The backlash underscored the difficulties some technology companies face in limiting the spread of Russian propaganda.
content: Far-right influencers have often encouraged people to use the small privacy-focused search engine DuckDuckGo instead of Google, saying that the giant search engine censored conservative ideas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Motyka
title: Leo Marx, 102, Dies; Studied Clash of Nature and Culture in America
description: His landmark book, “The Machine in the Garden,” explored the contradiction of a “pastoral ideal” and helped define the field of American studies.
content: Leo Marx, a cultural historian whose landmark book exploring the pervasive intrusion of technology on nature helped define the field of American studies, died on Tuesday at his home in Boston. He was 102.

title: Some New York restaurants still ask for proof of vaccination. One of them drew protesters.

content: About 20 people descended on a Greenwich Village restaurant on Tuesday night to protest its request that indoor diners provide proof of vaccination, a day after New York City dropped its requirement for the documentation.

title: Putin Is ‘Profoundly Anti-Modern.’ Masha Gessen Explains What That Means for the World.
description: The Russian American journalist on how Putin’s war in Ukraine is playing out inside Russia’s highly controlled media environment.
content: For Western audiences, the past few weeks have been a torrent of information about what’s happening in Russia and Ukraine. Daily updates of Russian military advances. Horrifying videos of buildings exploding and innocent civilians being killed. Announcements of increasingly severe economic sanctions and major corporate pullouts. Charts showing the collapse of the ruble. Story after story about the hardships facing the Russian economy.
source.name: The New York Times

title: U.S. and Allies Move to Further Isolate Russia From Global Economy
description: The Biden administration said it would join Europe and other allies in stripping Russia of permanent normal trade relations, another step to inflict economic damage on the country over its invasion of Ukraine.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden and other Western leaders moved on Friday to further isolate Russia from the global trading system, saying they would strip the country of normal trade relations and take other steps to sever its links to the world economy in response to President Vladimir V. Putin’s invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Wonking Out: Lies, Damned Lies and Gasoline Prices
description: Do Republicans think we’re stupid? Well, yes.
content: Let me offer two theories about recent events. You tell me which you find more credible.

title: Yes, You Can Make Salmon on the Stovetop Without the Smell
description: A simple dinner, which Genevieve Ko created for her college-bound daughter, also yielded a smart trick for silky, scentless fish.
content: There’s a line of shops on a tree-lined road in Dublin, with O’Briens Wine in the center, a butcher and grocer on either side and a minimart at the far end. Taken together, they have most everything you would need to prepare meals. I know, because I dragged my daughter into each store and examined every aisle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff
title: Europe’s Trains Take Fighters to Ukraine, and Bring Back Refugees
description: Built up over 150 years of conflicts that defined modern-day Europe, railways have played a central role in the continent’s peacetime integration. Now they’re back on a war footing.
content: ABOARD THE PRAGUE-PRZEMYSL TRAIN — On the 12th night of the war, on a platform at Prague’s central train station, Vitali Slobodianiuk and Volodymyr Kotsyuba met for the first time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Imbler
title: The New Captain of the Endurance Shipwreck Is an Anemone
description: A who’s who of the new invertebrate crew steering Ernest Shackleton’s sunken ship in the Weddell Sea.
content: Huw Griffiths, a marine bio-geographer at the British Antarctic Survey, was eating pancakes when news broke that the wreck of the Endurance — the famed ship helmed by Ernest Shackleton that sank in an expedition in 1915 — had been discovered.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: At Indian Wells, Ukrainian Tennis Stars Take Their Fight to the Court
description: Playing through fear of the war, Marta Kostyuk said that she must show “what it’s like having a Ukrainian heart” and that it “hurts” to see Russian players at the tournament.
content: INDIAN WELLS, Calif. — The Ukrainian teenager Marta Kostyuk and the Belgian veteran Maryna Zanevska played for more than three hours in the sun and a swirling wind.

title: A Brewing Rivalry Goes the Nets’ Way, for One Night
description: The Nets were amazing. The Philadelphia 76ers were awful.
content: Philadelphia turned out to celebrate and express itself in its own inimitable way. Around the time that Julius Erving and Allen Iverson were sharing a courtside hug, 76ers fans at the Wells Fargo Center were filing into the arena so they could boo Ben Simmons, a former member of their team, as he warmed up for a game in which he would not play.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Parents Relying on Ukraine Surrogates Desperately Seek Their Newborns
description: The Russian invasion has disrupted a thriving hub of legal commercial surrogacy. Some couples are risking trips into the war zone to get their children.

author: By Dave Philipps and Eric Schmitt
title: Over Ukraine, Lumbering Turkish-Made Drones Are an Ominous Sign for Russia
description: The Bayraktar TB2 has become a rallying symbol for Ukrainians, who are singing songs about them and posting videos of their success.
content: Ukraine’s most sophisticated attack drone is about as stealthy as a crop duster: slow, low-flying and completely defenseless. So when the Russian invasion began, many experts expected the few drones that the Ukrainian forces managed to get off the ground would be shot down in hours.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: 2 Dead After Driver Crashes Outside a Restaurant in Washington, D.C.
description: Three other people had life-threatening injuries after an older driver lost control of his vehicle and crashed into an outdoor dining area on Friday.
content: An older driver lost control of his vehicle and crashed into an outdoor seating area at a busy restaurant in Washington, D.C., at lunchtime on Friday, killing two women and leaving three other people with life-threatening injuries, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Pérez-Peña
title: Russia Batters and Encircles Ukrainian Cities, as Diplomacy Falters
description: The first meeting during the war of the two countries’ foreign ministers yielded no cease-fire. The Russian side signaled that its invasion would not stop until Ukraine surrendered.
content: The top diplomats of Russia and Ukraine failed to make even a hint of progress Thursday in their first face-to-face meeting since the Russian invasion began, while Russian bombardments spread more carnage in a two-week-old war that Ukraine estimated had already inflicted $100 billion in damage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: Requests for compassionate release filed by federal prisoners swelled during the pandemic, a study finds.
description: The number of requests for compassionate release filed by federal prisoners skyrocketed during the pandemic, according to a report by the U.S. Sentencing Commission released on Thursday, with risks associated with contracting Covid-19 a critical factor.
content: The number of requests for compassionate release filed by federal prisoners skyrocketed during the pandemic, according to a report by the U.S. Sentencing Commission released on Thursday, with risks associated with contracting Covid-19 a critical factor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Parisienne Scoop
description: And a very Weintraub Friday to you, dear readers.
content: FRIDAY PUZZLE — I was about three months into writing Wordplay when Robyn Weintraub made her debut in the New York Times Crossword in 2011. There was a dearth of women constructors being published — there still is — so I was happy to see Ms. Weintraub join our ranks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Terence McGinley
title: Demystifying the Uncertainty of Snowfall
description: A tool created by a team at The Upshot uses data from the National Weather Service to communicate the unpredictability of snowstorms.
content: A snowstorm is lurching across the country, up the coast or maybe in your area. The local meteorologist predicts 12 to 18 inches of snow, and the weather forecast stirs excitement and preparation: Nervous shoppers clear out the grocery store. Schools close. Maybe the trains shut down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Weinman
title: ‘He Got a Cigarette Stuck in His Neck, and He Took It Like a Man.’
description: Eli Cranor’s top-shelf debut, “Don’t Know Tough,” is Southern noir at its finest, a cauldron of terrible choices and even more terrible outcomes.
content: A common joke in crime fiction circles is that asking “What is noir?” will result in hours of unending argument. (I tend to go by the writer Jack Bludis’s definition: “hard-boiled = tough, noir = screwed.”) Eli Cranor’s top-shelf debut, DON’T KNOW TOUGH (Soho Crime, 322 pp., $24.95), is unmistakably noir in the Southern tradition, a cauldron of terrible choices and even more terrible outcomes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Oscar Rewind: When Rita Moreno Made History and Thanked No One
description: The actress explains why she gave one of the shortest Academy speeches ever when she became the first Latina to win an acting Oscar 60 years ago.
content: It was the night that cemented her place in history, and Rita Moreno almost skipped it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: A Rare Rainout Suspends Players Championship With Three Tied for Lead
description: Torrential rains flooded the fairways at T.C.P. Sawgrass, a course that already features multiple water hazards. The tournament won’t end before Monday.
content: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. — This year’s Players Championship, a signature event of the PGA Tour, will take an extra day to complete after torrential rains on Friday in northern Florida suspended play for a second consecutive day. Golfers endured Friday’s foul weather for only a few soggy hours at the T.P.C. Sawgrass golf course, one day after the first round was twice interrupted by rain delays and never completed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Meaney
title: Putin Wants a Clash of Civilizations. Is ‘The West’ Falling for It?
description: A clash of civilizations is never a good idea.
content: BERLIN — Amid the point-blank horror of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, the expanding war zone in Europe seems to have become a comfort zone for much of America’s political establishment. In his State of the Union address, President Biden declared that in the face of Vladimir Putin’s aggression, “we see a more unified Europe, a more unified West.” He is correct. Polish nationalists and European Union bureaucrats are sudden brothers in arms. Back at home, Republicans and Democrats have put aside differences on climate change and voting rights for an enemy who appears to have emerged from Cold War central casting: An evil empire is again on the march in Europe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Brooks
title: This Is Why Putin Can’t Back Down
description: The invasion of Ukraine is a rabid form of identity politics.
content: Carl von Clausewitz famously asserted that war is the continuation of politics by other means. The Russian invasion of Ukraine is the continuation of identity politics by other means.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Meghan Dansie
title: Climate Change’s Threat to the Glorious Redwood, Both Here and Afar
description: In 1936, foresters planted California redwoods in Victoria. How long will they grow in peace?
content: Framed by native eucalyptuses and ferns in a shady glade near Victoria’s famed Great Ocean Road, a group of Californian giants rises into the Australian sun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: He’s Springing Forward to Move City Clocks to Daylight Time
description: Marvin Schneider, the New York City clock master, has a busy weekend ahead.
content: Good morning. It’s Friday. We’ll look at how New York City’s clock master handles the change to daylight saving time. We’ll also check on a telephone number made famous by a song in the big band era.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ann Carrns
title: Government Site for Buying Savings Bonds Shows Its Age
description: The TreasuryDirect digital system requires old-school paper when customers update their linked bank account. That’s a particular concern as interest in inflation-indexed bonds surges.
content: As inflation has surged, many consumers have turned to the federal government’s online TreasuryDirect system to buy inflation-indexed savings bonds. But the 20-year-old website may be showing its age.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Bortz
title: How to Buy a Vacant Lot
description: Buying land is one way to get your dream house, but the rules can be much tougher. And you might have to source your own electricity.
content: To Vicky and Mickey Popat, it seemed as if everyone in Orlando, Fla., wanted to buy a house last spring. “The market here was so skimpy that any time a decent property got listed, it would receive multiple offers right away and get snatched up,” said Ms. Popat, 39.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: Your Induction Stove Is the First Step Toward Plugging In the Whole House
description: If you give up the open flame now, when it comes time to replace the furnace and water heater, you’ll be less reluctant to cap your gas line.
content: Of all the energy hogs in Joseph Mulvaney’s home, his gas range was not the biggest offender. But earlier this month, he replaced it with an induction one anyway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Qiu
title: Theory About U.S.-Funded Bioweapons Labs in Ukraine Is Unfounded
description: Prominent conservative voices have mischaracterized remarks from American officials to amplify baseless claims promoted by Russian state media.
content: WASHINGTON — Prominent social media users and conservative voices have amplified a baseless theory promoted by Russian state media accusing the United States of funding biological weapons laboratories in Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Mafia’s View of ‘The Godfather’ and the W.N.B.A. Star Detained in Russia: The Week in Narrated Articles
description: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
content: This weekend, listen to a collection of narrated articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed O'Loughlin
title: As Ireland’s Church Retreats, the Cult of a Female Saint Thrives
description: The cult of Saint Brigid, with its emphasis on nature and healing, and its shift away from the patriarchal faith of traditional Catholicism in Ireland, is attracting people from around the world.
content: KILDARE, Ireland — Around the year 480, as legend has it, a freed slave named Brigid founded a convent under an oak in the east of Ireland. To feed her followers, she asked the King of Leinster, who ruled the area, for a grant of land.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simbarashe Cha and Elizabeth Bristow
title: Fashion Week Style: Well Framed
description: Eyewear was everywhere during the fashion weeks of New York, London, Milan and Paris.
content: Throughout fashion month, which concluded this week in Paris, the photographer Simbarashe Cha was out on the sidewalks searching for moments of personal style. Everywhere he went, eyewear in an endless variety of shapes and colors was on display. Here are some of the best frames he saw in four cities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson and Katie Rogers
title: Biden will call for suspending normal trade relations with Russia.
description: The move, expected to be joined by the G7 and the European Union, would result in higher tariffs on Russian products being sent to the United States.
content: President Biden will announce on Friday that the United States will join the G7 and the European Union in calling for the suspension of normal trade relations with Russia, according to a person familiar with the announcement, a change that would raise tariffs for many Russian products.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Schmall and Hari Kumar
title: India Election Victory Is Expanding a Hindu Monk’s National Profile
description: Yogi Adityanath’s return as chief minister of Uttar Pradesh is fueling talk that he might succeed Narendra Modi as prime minister one day, and continue to advance their Hindu political movement.
content: GORAKHPUR, India — The powerful chief minister of India’s most populous state woke up at a Hindu temple, fed cows sweet jaggery cakes, performed a religious ceremony for Lord Shiva, then hit the trail on the last day of his election campaign this month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Man Charged With Pushing a Capitol Police Officer Over a Ledge on Jan. 6
description: The F.B.I. said it had identified Ralph Joseph Celentano III from a photo on Facebook and Instagram that showed him attending a fund-raiser for a sea turtle foundation.
content: A New York man was arrested on Wednesday and charged with shoving a Capitol Police officer over a ledge on Jan. 6, 2021, when a mob of Trump supporters disrupted Congress as it was certifying the 2020 election results, prosecutors said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Fuller
title: San Francisco Mayor Replaces Ousted School Board Members
description: The new members announced on Friday, three weeks after a recall election created three vacancies, are women from diverse backgrounds.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Three weeks after a decisive vote to recall members of the San Francisco school board, the city’s mayor filled the vacated positions on Friday with a slate of parents who she said would tend to the “urgent needs” of the city’s public school students.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: An inquiry into the U.K. government’s pandemic response will include a focus on bereaved families.
description: A public inquiry into the British government’s handling of the coronavirus crisis will aim to understand the experiences of bereaved families and disparities in the effect of the pandemic on different groups, Prime Minister Boris Johnson said on Thursday.
content: A public inquiry into the British government’s handling of the coronavirus crisis will aim to understand the experiences of bereaved families and disparities in the effect of the pandemic on different groups, Prime Minister Boris Johnson said on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer
title: ‘Stealth’ Omicron Is Stealthy No More: What’s Known About the BA.2 Variant
description: The subvariant of Omicron is not yet causing a new surge in the United States and probably won’t.
content: As the Omicron coronavirus surge subsides, researchers are keeping an eye on a highly transmissible subvariant known as BA.2. Although it doesn’t appear to have the capacity to drive a large new wave of infections, the variant could potentially slow the current decline of Covid cases and make treatments more difficult.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Disney Can’t Hide From Politics
description: Companies may need to accept that they have become part of the political process, whether they like it or not.
content: The Walt Disney Company has a big problem. It wants to be loved by everybody: Massachusetts liberals and Mississippi conservatives, Muslims in Saudi Arabia and atheists in China. It therefore prefers to minimize the number of times it takes stands on hot-button social issues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: ‘We Live in a Different World Now’: Dispatch From a Changed Germany
description: A stunned country rearms.
content: BERLIN — Nils Schmid, a member of Germany’s Parliament and a foreign policy spokesman for the Social Democratic Party, was explaining to me what a minor role the military plays in his country’s politics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Roman Abramovich and the End of Soccer’s Oligarch Era
description: Stripped of its Russian benefactor, Chelsea now faces a reckoning. Soccer’s will come next.
content: There were, over the years, three stories that explained how Roman Abramovich washed ashore at Chelsea. Each one, now, serves as a kind of time capsule, a carbon-dated relic from a specific period, capturing in amber each stage of our understanding of what, precisely, soccer has become.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong
title: U.S. Fights Bioweapons Disinformation Pushed by Russia and China
description: The Biden administration says the two countries’ promotion of anti-U.S. conspiracy theories might be cover for lethal Russian military operations.
content: WASHINGTON — One of Russia’s most incendiary disinformation campaigns ramped up days ago, when its defense and foreign ministries issued statements falsely claiming that the Pentagon was financing biological weapons labs in Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: The U.S. and the E.U., aiming to punish oligarchs, ban luxury exports to Russia.
description: The move will prevent any shipments of high-end watches, cars, apparel, alcohol and jewelry from reaching the country.
content: Hermès scarves, Harry Winston jewels, Feadship yachts, Mercedes cars, Cognac and Champagne — none of these public badges of achievement and culture will be available to oligarchs in Russia any more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: The Latest News From Ukraine and California’s Response
description: How Gov. Gavin Newsom is handling Russian sanctions and more.
content: Given the fast-changing situation in Ukraine and the mounting death toll, I’ll be using today’s newsletter to guide you through our coverage of the war as well as some stories with particular relevance to California readers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simran Hans
title: Skewering the Anxious Young Things
description: The film “All My Friends Hate Me” satirizes anxiety and paranoia among upper-class British millennials. Its writers say they are laughing at themselves most of all.
content: LONDON — Seven years ago, Tom Stourton, 35, received a wedding invitation from two college friends. He was surprised, having drifted apart from the couple. But he attended the event, arriving hung over and sleep deprived from another party the night before.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John McWhorter
title: Ukrainian Isn’t ‘Little Russian’ and Black English Isn’t Broken
description: Getting to this recognition will take redoubled efforts.
content: It was long ago common for Russians to regard Ukrainian as just a dialect of Russian. “Little Russian,” it was called. Writing for The Conversation this week, Florida International University’s Phillip Carter said, “If you ask some Russian nationalists, Ukrainian isn’t a language at all,” noting that in the 1863 Valuev Circular, Pyotr Valuev, Russia’s interior minister, decreed that a separate Ukrainian language did not exist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: U.S. Official Ends Sentence of Terrorist Who Was Tortured by C.I.A.
description: Majid Khan, who confessed to war crimes and turned informant in 2012, will not go free from Guantánamo Bay until U.S. diplomats find a country to take him in.
content: GUANTÁNAMO BAY, Cuba — A confessed courier for Al Qaeda whose tale of torture by the C.I.A. disgusted a U.S. military jury has completed his prison sentence, the Pentagon announced Friday. Now U.S. diplomats have to find a place for him to go.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: How We Verify Our Reporting on the Ukraine War
description: To cut through the fog of propaganda and misinformation on both sides, The Times has deployed dozens of  journalists  to Ukraine to witness events as they unfold.
content: The Times has deployed dozens of reporters, photographers, videographers, audio journalists, writers and others to Ukraine and the countries bordering it to deliver real-time, independent, in-depth coverage of the conflict and its reverberations across the region. Times journalists are witnessing events on the ground as they unfold, reporting from battlefields, hospitals, improvised bomb shelters and contested cities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Acrostic
description: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon make us take our time.
content: ACROSTIC — Once I figured out the unusual second word in this acrostic, at the very end of my solve, I felt a strong sense of déjà vu. Didn’t we just see it in another puzzle? Well, not quite; it appeared in the clue set of an acrostic from 21 years ago. The curiosities of memory and time go well with the source of today’s passage, which is a book by Alan Burdick called “Why Time Flies: A Mostly Scientific Investigation,” from 2017.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: Russian Demands to Ease Sanctions Halt Nuclear Talks With Iran
description: Russia has injected its fight against sanctions into talks aimed at restoring a nuclear agreement with Iran. The Russian demands have delayed the prospect of a deal.
content: BRUSSELS — Russian demands that a revised nuclear agreement with Iran shield it from sanctions imposed because of its war in Ukraine halted efforts to revive the deal on Friday, just as negotiators said they had all but finalized the agreement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac, Ryan Mac and Sheera Frenkel
title: Facebook’s Parent Company Will Make Employees Do Their Own Laundry
description: The company told workers on Friday that it will reduce or eliminate some of its famous perks as it prepares for a return to the office.
content: The salad days of Facebook’s lavish employee perks may be coming to an end.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Wall Street Joins the Unbanking of Russia
description: Goldman and JPMorgan are the first big U.S. lenders to pull out of the country.
content: Goldman Sachs yesterday became the first major global bank to say it was quitting Russia, followed shortly after by JPMorgan Chase. The Wall Street giants join a growing list of multinational companies that have pledged to stop doing business in Russia. “None of us can fail to see this for what it is: the invasion of a sovereign state,” David Solomon, Goldman’s C.E.O., wrote in a memo to employees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles, Caryn Ganz, Giovanni Russonello and Lindsay Zoladz
title: Megan Thee Stallion and Dua Lipa’s Sultry Team-Up, and 10 More New Songs
description: Hear tracks by Floating Points, Miranda Lambert, Tinashe and others.
content: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Prosecutors to Drop Murder Charge in Fatal Shooting After Right-Wing Rally in Denver
description: The district attorney’s office said it was not able to overcome Matthew Dolloff’s claim that he had acted in “self-defense or defense of others” when he shot Lee John Keltner in 2020.
content: Prosecutors said on Thursday that they planned to drop a second-degree murder charge against a former security guard for a Denver television news station who fatally shot a man in a confrontation after a right-wing rally in 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Late Night Casts Doubt on the Russian-Ukrainian Peace Talks
description: Trevor Noah warned viewers not to get their hopes up: “Not only did Russia not agree to end the war; it wouldn’t even admit that it started a war.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Carmel
title: Rusty Mae Moore, Transgender Educator and Activist, Dies at 80
description: Ms. Moore, a business professor, sheltered numerous people, including the activist Sylvia Rivera, in her Park Slope home, which came to be known as Transy House.
content: Rusty Mae Moore, a transgender educator and activist who housed numerous transgender people in the 1990s and 2000s in her Brooklyn home, a de facto shelter that became known as Transy House, died on Feb. 23 at her home in Pine Hill, N.Y., in the Catskills. She was 80.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Vrentas and Kevin Draper
title: Deshaun Watson Won’t Face Criminal Charges in Houston Cases, Grand Jury Decides
description: A grand jury heard evidence Friday to consider criminal charges against the Texans quarterback accused last year by two dozen women of lewd behavior. He was also deposed in two civil lawsuits.
content: HOUSTON — Deshaun Watson, the 26-year-old N.F.L. quarterback who has been accused by two dozen women of sexual misconduct during massage appointments, will not be criminally charged in Houston, a grand jury decided Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: ‘Magic Could Happen’
description: The star milers of Newbury Park High School are getting a crash course in celebrity as they seek to crush a record. Catch them if you can. (You can’t.)
content: THOUSAND OAKS, Calif. — The country’s fastest high school distance runners were circling the track on a recent weeknight as Andrew Young dangled from the back of a speeding golf cart with his camera. Young’s twin sons, Lex and Leo, whose YouTube channel has nearly 13,000 followers, had enlisted their father to record their team’s workout for posterity. The problem was they kept outrunning the golf cart.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hillary Richard
title: Wolves, and Misinformation About Them, Make a California Comeback
description: For the past 10 years, wolves have been steadily returning to the state after being wiped out a century ago. But not everyone is rolling out the welcome mat.
content: Kent Laudon, a wolf biologist with the California Department of Fish and Wildlife, woke up one morning last year to a flurry of text messages from a rancher in the state’s northernmost county. He was asking about a post with wildly specific details spreading across Facebook that urged people to find a red truck that was transporting breeding wolves along Route 97 into Siskiyou County, Calif. Mr. Laudon was not surprised. This wasn’t the first post of its kind, and it wouldn’t be the last.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes, Michael Forsythe, David D. Kirkpatrick and Jason Horowitz
title: U.S. Officials Say Superyacht Could be Putin’s
description: They say they have indications that the $700 million, 459-foot yacht, which is in dry dock in Italy, is associated with the Russian president, backing an earlier claim by a former crew member.
content: WASHINGTON — American officials are examining the ownership of a $700 million superyacht currently in a dry dock at an Italian seacoast town, and believe it could be associated with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, according to multiple people briefed on the information.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson
title: Hong Kong’s overwhelmed hospitals are keeping the dead in wards with Covid patients.
description: For several weeks, bodies have been piling up at hospitals because the city’s public mortuaries, which can take up to 3,000 bodies, are full.
content: It’s an image that shocked many: bodies of the dead piled up next to Covid patients.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Timothy Noah
title: The Democrats’ Historic Successes and Contemporary Failures
description: Two books, “What It Took to Win,” by Michael Kazin, and “Left Behind,” by Lily Geismer, trace the history of the Democratic Party from its origins down to the present.
content: WHAT IT TOOK TO WINA History of the Democratic PartyBy Michael KazinLEFT BEHINDThe Democrats’ Failed Attempt to Solve InequalityBy Lily Geismer
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Bailey
title: ‘My Cousin Vinny’ at 30: An Unlikely Oscar Winner
description: Much like Vinny in the South, the film was a fish out of water at the Academy Awards. But the comedy endures, thanks to a generous Joe Pesci and a fiery Marisa Tomei.
content: When the culture-clash courtroom comedy “My Cousin Vinny” landed in theaters on March 13, 1992, the critical response was mostly positive. The Times’s Vincent Canby found it “inventive and enjoyable,” The Los Angeles Times’s Peter Rainer called it “often funny” and The Hollywood Reporter deemed it “a terrific variation on the fish-out-of-water/man-from-Mars story formula.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs and Robert Chiarito
title: Jussie Smollett Sentenced to Jail for False Report of a Hate Crime
description: The actor was sentenced to five months in jail after being convicted last year of filing a false police report that said he had been the victim of a racist and homophobic attack.
content: A judge in Chicago sentenced Jussie Smollett to five months in jail on Thursday, ordering that the actor be incarcerated for falsely reporting to the police that he had been the victim of a racist and homophobic attack in 2019.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: The Price of Putin’s Belligerence
description: Sanctions could crush Russia’s economy. Will they actually help Ukraine?
content: As his ruthless invasion continues, Vladimir Putin is trying to break Ukraine by demolishing its cities and brutalizing its people. Each day brings fresh horrors. A family killed while crossing a bridge to safety. Fathers and children touching hands and parting. A maternity hospital blasted into pieces in Mariupol, where roughly half a million people are under siege.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs and Robert Chiarito
title: Jussie Smollett, Once an ‘Empire’ Star, Is Now in the Cook County Jail
description: On Thursday evening, Mr. Smollett began serving a five-month sentence for falsely reporting a hate crime, a conviction he plans to appeal.
content: It was an extraordinary ending to an unusual hearing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Parker-Pope
title: What’s the Best Way to Cope in an Anxious World? Do Something.
description: One way to loosen the grip of anxiety is to focus on helping someone else.
content: Many people are experiencing a jumbled mix of emotions right now. There’s sadness and a feeling of helplessness about the brutal attacks against the people of Ukraine, as well as anxiety and fear about the threat of nuclear weapons. Add to that exhaustion after two years of worrying about a deadly virus. And for some, there’s also guilt, for the indulgence of talking about anxious feelings at a time when others are suffering far more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaine Glusac
title: As the Omicron Wave Subsides, Travel Insurance Claims Crawl
description: Getting a decision on a claim has become the latest problem consumers are experiencing with travel insurance. Here’s how to avoid delays.
content: Before the pandemic, Lauren Mack, 44, a writer based in New York City, “did not routinely purchase travel insurance,” she wrote in an email. Covid-19 convinced her otherwise, and of six trips taken since the onset of the pandemic, she has had to file claims for three — twice for weather delays and once because her travel companion tested positive for the virus. Two are still under review, and the first took nearly two months from claim to reimbursement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon
title: Bye Bye Iowa? Democrats to Debate Changes to Primary Calendar
description: After complaints about disenfranchisement and logistical snafus, the party is reconsidering Iowa and New Hampshire’s coveted spots in the presidential nominating process.
content: For years, Democrats in Iowa and New Hampshire have battled criticism from others in the party who argued that the two states are not racially diverse enough to kick off the Democratic nomination process.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raja Abdulrahim
title: Russian Sieges of Ukrainian Cities Provoke Bitter Recollections for Syrians
description: “We feel for them and say, may God be with you,” said one Syrian who endured hunger and cold when his own government, backed by Russia, besieged Aleppo.
content: Huda Khayti endured years of deprivation under siege by Syrian government forces in a rebel-held Damascus suburb. The thing she said she remembers most is the screams of her neighbors’ hungry children in the middle of the night.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How People First Arrived in the Americas
description: Jennifer Raff talks about “Origin,” and Ira Rutkow discusses “Empire of the Scalpel.”
content: Scholars have long believed that the first Americans arrived via land bridge some 13,000 years ago, when retreating glaciers created an inland corridor from Siberia. Jennifer Raff, an anthropological geneticist at the University of Kansas, tells a different story in “Origin.” According to Raff, the path to the Americas was coastal rather than inland, and what we’ve thought of as a bridge was a homeland inhabited for millenniums. Raff talks about the book on this week’s podcast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Porter
title: Burberry’s Alternate Fashion Reality
description: The British brand holds a post-London Fashion Week show.
content: LONDON — Call it London Fashion Lunchtime.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Block
title: Those Lucky Coins Paid Off
description: Kelly MacDonald bet on his improbable romance with Ashleigh Dopp by giving her loonies, Canadian currency with an auspicious reputation.

content: Good morning. It’s getting toward ice-out season in some parts of the country, everything melting, making way for buds and flowers. It’s not pretty. (In Vermont, they call it mud season. Maine, too. In Alaska, it’s breakup.) Everything’s dirty, everything’s wet. But that little softness in the air? Those pale green shoots in the wrecked grass at the park? They are promise of a lovely season to come, even if the act of writing those words will no doubt bring one last vicious snowstorm to my door.
